intro: Tetramolopium arenarium, commonly known as sand dune hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to arid and coastal regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves. The plant produces showy, five-petaled yellow flowers that bloom in late summer and early fall. It thrives in sandy soils and is well adapted to withstand drought and high salinity. Its ecological role includes providing nectar for pollinators and stabilizing sand dunes.
